title: Android Weekly Issue #647
description: Articles & Tutorials Sponsored Introducing a New Approach to Mobile App Security Join Guardsquare to learn more about our new guided configuration approach to mobile application protection. Our latest innovation ensures that all developers, regardless of their security knowledge, can effortlessly launch apps with industry-leading protection - in less than a day. Register now. Google Maps in Jetpack Compose: Circles With the basics of Google Maps in Compose from a previous post, Joe Birch dives into the Circle composable and learn how we can draw circular indicators on a map. Getting Started with Koin Annotations 1.4 in Compose Multiplatform In this guide, Arnaud walks you through migrating a simple Compose Multiplatform application from Koin DSL to the new Koin Annotations 1.4. Sponsored Come to our mobile engineering meetup in SF RSVP to join Runway’s Nov 20th meetup at Sentry’s San Francisco HQ to hear from a panel of experts about how to holistically monitor mobile release health and run better rollouts. Plus eat, drink, network, and hang out with other members of the mobile community. Thoughts on Kotlin Multi Platform (KMP) Benjamin considers the first experience with Kotlin MultiPlatform (KMP), sharing thoughts and aspirations for the technology. Compose Navigation The Old Way Davies Adedayo AbdulGafar walks through how to safely define Navigation string routes, break down the structure of these routes, and address common problems encountered when using this method. Widgets with Glance: Blending in Katie Barnett shows how with Jetpack Compose Glance you can easily theme your widgets to use dynamic colors. Kotlin Multiplatform — How to improve the iOS development experience Guilherme Delgado explores a range of helpful techniques aimed at improving the development workflow in KMP projects. Koin: My Favorite Dependency Injection Library for Android Explore why Koin is Stefano Natali's favorite DI library and how you can use it effectively in your Android projects. Using Vertex AI in a Compose/Kotlin Multiplatform project John O'Reilly shows how to use the Vertex AI Android and iOS SDKs in a Compose/Kotlin Multiplatform project. Parameterized Android Tests with Burst 2.0 Sam Edwards considers how Burst 2.0 seems like the right solution to run parameterized tests and for sharded test runners to deterministically compute all test method names using static analysis. Place a sponsored post Advertise your Android dev course to over 80k readers We reach out to more than 80k Android developers around the world, every week, through our email newsletter and social media channels. Advertise your Android development course! Jobs Staff Android Software Engineer - Native SDKs (Remote (US)) We're seeking a Staff Android Engineer to redefine how observability data is collected and consumed. You’ll lead the development of innovative SDKs and libraries to create seamless and high-performance products. Join us to revolutionize mobile observability! Libraries & Code Film-Simulator FilmSimulator is a cross-platform mobile application developed using Kotlin Multiplatform and Compose UI Multiplatform. The app allows users to apply different film-like LUTs (Look-Up Tables) to their images, providing a unique aesthetic reminiscent of classic film styles. burst Burst is a library for parameterizing unit tests implemented as a Kotlin compiler plug-in. Burst supports all Kotlin platforms and works great in multiplatform projects. News Kotlin Multiplatform parameterized tests with Burst Jesse Wilson announces Burst 2.0, a Gradle plug-in that adds support for parameterized tests to Kotlin/Multiplatform projects. Kotlin Multiplatform Development Roadmap for 2025 Egor Tolstoy examines how JetBrains is focused on enhancing the Kotlin Multiplatform ecosystem in 2025, including upgrading Compose Multiplatform for iOS to Stable. Videos & Podcasts Bittersweet beginnings - Fragmented They’re back from the hiatus with a SemiQuicentennial episode! With the momentous 250 comes some big announcements and a shift in the way they do things. Koin the Secret to Fast & Simple Dependency Injection Daniel Atitienei implement Koin in an Android app and discuss some differences between it and Hilt. Dangerous Minds: How we're getting developer education wrong with David Rawson This talk examines common advice aimed at beginners in Kotlin and Android development and shows how these can actually harm both codebases and, long term, the career trajectories of new software engineers. TypeAlias Show #3 - Immutable and Persistent Lists • Subtyping Composables Dave Leeds checks the Compose Multiplatform 1.7 updates, explores the Immutable Collections library and examines how we can subtype Composables. Navigation In Multi-Module Android Apps - Why You're Doing It Wrong! Philipp Lackner shares the correct way of implementing navigation in a multi-module Android project. Learn how Android devs are getting the most out of Gemini in Android Studio Gemini in Android Studio just got a huge update, making it useful across every stage of the dev lifecycle. Gemini in Android Studio: now helping you at every stage of the dev life cycle Gemini in Android Studio is your AI powered coding companion and it’s getting the biggest set of updates since launch. For the first time, Gemini is bringing AI to every stage of the development lifecycle. More frequent Android SDK releases, and a look into updates on Android Google announced that Android will have more frequent SDK releases going forward, with two releases planned in 2025 with new developer APIs. AnchoredDraggable | Compose Tips Jossi Wolf covers Compose AnchoredDraggable, which is a Jetpack Compose API that lets you build components that can be dragged between anchor points and settles an anchor point at the end of the gesture. Google Play PolicyBytes - October 2024 policy updates Paul, from Regional Operations North America, Trust and Safety, Google Play, shares important updates from our October 2024 Google Play policy announcements. How Compose Compiler Plugin Works mohit examines the architecture of the Compose compiler plug and how IR is transformed for the different part of the composable method.

Join Guardsquare to learn more about our new guided configuration approach to mobile application protection. Our latest innovation ensures that all developers, regardless of their security knowledge, can effortlessly launch apps with industry-leading protection - in less than a day. Register now.

With the basics of Google Maps in Compose from a previous post, Joe Birch dives into the Circle composable and learn how we can draw circular indicators on a map.

RSVP to join Runway’s Nov 20th meetup at Sentry’s San Francisco HQ to hear from a panel of experts about how to holistically monitor mobile release health and run better rollouts. Plus eat, drink, network, and hang out with other members of the mobile community.

Davies Adedayo AbdulGafar walks through how to safely define Navigation string routes, break down the structure of these routes, and address common problems encountered when using this method.

Sam Edwards considers how Burst 2.0 seems like the right solution to run parameterized tests and for sharded test runners to deterministically compute all test method names using static analysis.

We're seeking a Staff Android Engineer to redefine how observability data is collected and consumed. You’ll lead the development of innovative SDKs and libraries to create seamless and high-performance products. Join us to revolutionize mobile observability!

FilmSimulator is a cross-platform mobile application developed using Kotlin Multiplatform and Compose UI Multiplatform. The app allows users to apply different film-like LUTs (Look-Up Tables) to their images, providing a unique aesthetic reminiscent of classic film styles.

Burst is a library for parameterizing unit tests implemented as a Kotlin compiler plug-in. Burst supports all Kotlin platforms and works great in multiplatform projects.

They’re back from the hiatus with a SemiQuicentennial episode! With the momentous 250 comes some big announcements and a shift in the way they do things.

Jossi Wolf covers Compose AnchoredDraggable, which is a Jetpack Compose API that lets you build components that can be dragged between anchor points and settles an anchor point at the end of the gesture.

mohit examines the architecture of the Compose compiler plug and how IR is transformed for the different part of the composable method.
